Abstract
Water borne pathogens pose a great threat to the health-care system and their mitigation poses a formidable challenge prompting researchers to find innovative and effective methods for pathogen control. Large scale implementation technologies for wastewater treatment need to be economical and facile. We have utilized industrial waste from citrus fruits to develop green nano-biocomposite materials. Green nano-biosynthesis methods are known to be cost effective, non-toxic and environment friendly that have attracted attention recently. The present study utilized citrus industry waste raw Citrus limetta peels as bio-reducing and stabilizing agents directly, instead of extract for the synthesis of silver nanoparticles. Characterization of the synthesized silver nanoparticles by X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) confirmed the impregnation of nano-silver with size range of 5-10 nm inside Citrus limetta peels that has been designated as CL-AgNPs. Antibacterial activity of CL-AgNPs was evaluated against the most prevalent waterborne pathogens for treating waste water from domestic and municipalities. The antibacterial activity was linked to nano-silver’s membrane permeabilization mode using LIVE/DEAD staining technique. The antibacterial potential of CL-AgNPs was also tested in batch and continuous experiments separately, which showed attenuation in bacterial load within 5 min exposure of CL-AgNPs as demonstrated by growth kinetics study. Furthermore, CL-AgNPs was found to be safe and did not exhibit cytotoxiceffects on human red blood cells (RBCs) up to 10X MIC. These findings infer that CL-AgNPs could be employed for cost-effective treatment of contaminated waste water after process optimization. Jo ur n l P re -p r of

1. Introduction:
Water borne diseases are linked to significant health burden across the globe. As per World health organization estimates, water borne diarrheal diseases are responsible for 2 million deaths annually. Domestic sewage contains millions of pathogenic microbes that are infectious and require their elimination before reuse of water. Proper household and community wastewater treatment methods can decrease the water borne infections significantly [1].
All type of water bodies can get affected due to the dreadful pathogens capable of causing adverse impact on public health [2]. The situation has been compounded by the emergence of antibiotic resistant bacterial species. Novel antibacterial strategies with a potential to mitigate both Gram-positive and Gram- negative bacterial pathogens with desired efficacy and high activity have gained attention in recent times [3-6].

Chlorination has been in practice for disinfection, however formation of chlorine induced carcinogenic components with undesired taste is a drawback for the implementation of this technology [7]. This drives researchers to look out for economically viable, ecofriendly strategies for the disinfection process. Inorganic nanoparticles have attracted substantial interest for the treatment of contaminated water due to its higher intrinsic reactivity, high surface to volume ratio with size and shape dependent properties [8]. Some metals like silver also exhibit extraordinary antibacterial properties due to peculiar biological, physical and chemical activities [9-14].
Metal (Ag, Au and Cu) nanoparticles have become popular for their implementation in water purification with a motive for pathogen cessation [15,16]. Many synthesis routes such as thermal decomposition, microwave irradiation, chemical reduction, electrochemical, solvothermal and bio-reduction using organisms have been in practice for the metal nanoparticles [17-23]. The above mentioned synthesis routes are energy intensive and require chemical reducing agents which are not eco-friendly. Further, the challenges of dedicated synthesis set-ups, size distribution and shape control of particles need to be addressed to achieve the required properties. Green synthesis using biological systems for nanoparticles using plant or plant extracts is becoming popular as the methods are less expensive, eco-friendly and safe for human therapeutic use [24-26]. Silver nanoparticles (Ag-NPs) synthesized using such plants/plant extracts have been shown to inhibit the growth of pathogenic bacteria of different classes without generating any harmful disinfection byproducts [27-30]. As such, silver nanoparticles have found wide range of applications in medicine, pharmacy, textile, cosmetology and water purification [31]. Plant extracts such as Citrus sinensis [32], aloe vera [33], lemon peels Jo ur na l P re -p

[34], papaya peels [35], banana peels [36] and honey [37] have been reported for the biosynthesis of silver nanoparticles.
To the best of knowledge, AgNps was synthesized by extracts of different materials. However, in the current study raw peels of Citrus fruits have been considered as biowaste which is cheap, readily available and biodegradable. Tons of Citrus peels are produced as waste from processing of Citrus fruits by various food industries [38]. The current research work aims to implement raw Citrus limetta (C.limetta) peels for the synthesis of silver nanoparticles. Citrus Peel components acted as good reducing agent as well as capping agent for the reduction of silver ions to nanoparticles. The variation of pH on silver metal loading was evaluated and optimum pH was determined for the maximum loading of the silver. The characterization of silver impregnated biomaterial was performed using SEM-EDX, TEM and XRD to analyze the as-prepared material in terms of size, morphology, composition and structure. Furthermore, its antibacterial activity against different water borne pathogens has been established. To show the field applicability of the method, sludge from wastewater treatment plant was collected and the developed material was tested for its bactericidal activity both in batch and continuous operations separately. Toxicity of the developed material (CL-AgNPs) was also evaluated on Red Blood Cells.
2. Materials and methods 2.1. Chemicals and materials
Citrus limetta peels which were used as reducing agents were collected from local juice center located in Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee, India. Silver nitrate

All the experiments were performed using double distilled water from Milli-Q water purification system (Millipore, Mumbai, India). Bacterial strains used in this study were obtained from the lab strain collection. The LIVE/DEAD BacLight Bacterial Viability Kit was procured from Thermo-Fisher, India.
2.2. Preparation of peel powder and pH variation on metal loading
Raw peels were washed thoroughly with milli-Q water (resistivity of 18.2 MΩ.cm) to remove any contaminates. The washed peels were incised into small pieces and rewashed with double distilled water. Later sliced peels were pulverized and sieved into fine powder. To know the influence of solution pH on metal loading, 1 mM solution of AgNO3 was used for impregnation at pH range of 2-10 by adjusting it with a suitable acid and base [39,40]. Following this, 1 g of peel powder was mixed with 10 mL of 1 mM AgNO3 solution for 48 h to impregnate metal into citrus peels. During impregnation, the pH of the solution becomes unstable and hence a secondary adjustment was made at regular intervals. After metal impregnation, the biomass was separated using sterile Whatman no 1 filter. The filtered biomass was washed three times with milli-Q water and further subjected to air dry. At optimum pH (zero-point charge), 20 g of C. limetta peel powder was impregnated with 200 mL of 1 mM silver salt solution for a contact time of 48 h. After filtration, treated biomass was dried and biomaterial Citrus limetta peel silver nanoparticles (CL-AgNPs) (fig. S1) was taken for further studies. Jo ur n l P re -p

2.3. Material characterization
The metal loading in the biomass was determined using ICP-MS (Perkin Elmer, Model- ELAN DRC-e). FTIR was performed in the wavelength range 4000-400 cm-1 using a Thermo Scientific Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer in order to identify the functional groups of in the newly developed material. The crystallinity of the synthesized material with the associated metal and their oxides was examined using X-ray diffractometer (D8-Adavnace), operated at 40KV and 30mA. The XRD spectrum was recorded by CuKα radiation with λ = 0.15406 nm. XRD spectra was analyzed using X’PERT Highscore software. The scanning was done in the region of 2θ from 5 to 90° [32]. XPS was performed to determine the oxidation states of metal (PHI 5000 VersaProbe III) [41]. The morphology and elemental composition of biomaterial CLAgNPs was examined using SEM-EDX (FE-SEM QUANTA 200 FEG). In addition, HRTEM (JEOL-JEM-3200FS) was employed to determine the particle size distribution. For HRTEM analysis, powdered sample was ultra-sonicated in ethanol so that silver particles get dispersed and a small drop was casted onto a carbon coated copper grid (purchased from TED PELLA, INC) which was allowed to dry before analysis [32].

The antibacterial activity of both biomaterials CL-AgNPs and C. limetta peels extract (as control) was tested against common water borne pathogens like Staphylococcus aureus ATCC 29213, Methicillin resistant S. aureus (MRSA-ST4423), Escherichia coli ATCC 25922, Escherichia coli O157:H7, Klebsiella pneumonia (KNC233),

Pseudomonas aeruginosa (RPT-56), Salmonella typhi, and Salmonella typhimurium ATCC 13311 by disc diffusion method as per Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines [42].
2.4.2. Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) calculation
Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of both biomaterials CL-AgNPs and C. limetta peels extract was determined by the broth micro-dilution method as per CLSI guideline [43].
2.5. Batch and continuous experiments
Continuous and batch experiments were used to assess the effect of the exposure of both CL-AgNPs and Citrus peels on common water borne pathogens in terms of reduction in microbial load (CFU/mL) using wastewater from wastewater treatment plant (WWTP) Haridwar India. For batch experiments, 0.5 g of biomaterial CL-AgNPs was allowed to mix with 9 mL of waste sludge in a 10 mL beaker at 0.78 g on magnetic stirrer (fig. S2a). The samples of the treated slurry were collected at regular intervals of time (5-10 min) and analyzed for microbial count and later compared with untreated control. The continuous experiments were performed in lab scale packed column set up (fig. S2b). About 0.5 g of biomaterial CL-AgNPs was packed between the packing material (glass wool) with a continuous flow through the packed column and the samples were collected at time intervals of 2 min. Nearly, 50µL of treated/untreated samples were spread on Mueller Hinton Agar (MHA) plates and plates were incubated at 37ºC for 14 h. After incubation bacterial colonies was counted, which was later expressed in colony forming unit per mL of sample (CFU/mL). Duplicate experiments were performed twice and the average performance of all experiments with the samples was reported here.
2.6. Membrane permeabilization assays
The ability of both biomaterials CL-AgNPs and C. limetta peels extract to permeabilize the bacterial membrane was examined by Propidium Iodide (PI) uptake assay as per method described earlier [44]. Bacterial cells (S. aureus ATCC 29213 and E. coli O157:H7) were grown in Mueller Hinton Broth (MHB) upto the mid logarithmic phase, harvested, washed, and adjusted to 106 CFU/mL in phosphate buffer saline (PBS). The cells were incubated with CL-AgNPs and C. limetta peels extract (1X MIC) at 37°C for 2 h. Cells were washed in PBS buffer and incubated with PI (1.5 mg/L) at 37°C for another 20 min in dark. The PI fluorescence was measured at excitation and emission of 544 nm and 620 nm respectively, using a SpectraMax M2e plate reader (Molecular Devices). Microscopic determination of membrane integrity was made by using the LIVE/DEAD BacLight assay kit as per the manufacturer instructions.

The morphology of bacterial cells (S. aureus ATCC 29213 and E. coli O157:H7) was examined post treatment with both biomaterials CL-AgNPs and C. limetta peels extract using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM). As previously described [45], the exponential phase of both bacterial cells were diluted to an OD600 of 0.2 with sterile PBS and incubated at 37°C for 2 h with 1× MIC of both CL-AgNPs and C. limetta peels extract. 3. Results and Discussion 3.1. Ag loading onto citrus peels
The pH of solution played a key role during the impregnation of metal into the biomass. Fluctuation in pH value leads to charge change in phytochemicals that are naturally present in biomass affecting their ability to reduce and bind metal ions. This in turn may affect the size and shape of the nanoparticles [46]. The impact of pH on metal loading was evaluated using ICP-MS over the pH range of 2-10. Since, pH varies during the impregnation, the final pH was noted and plotted against initial pH. The point where this curve intersects the 45° line is usually termed as zero point charge. Metal loading has been found to be maximum at pHzpc. The same was verified using the quantitative analysis of ICP-MS data obtained for metal impregnated CL peels. From Fig. 1a, we infer that the optimum pH for metal loading on CL peels appears at pH 4.5. If pH<pHZPC, then the solution becomes positively charged, the condition in which H+ and free Ag+ ions strive for sorbent active sites which hampers the loading of metal onto the biomass [40]. For pH>pHZPC, it develops a negative charge throughout solution which forms the hydroxides of metal resulting in the increase of metal loading onto the biomass. Fig. 1b, infers that maximum loading of metal occur at pH 4.5 of about 4.037 milli mole of Ag/kg J u n l P epr

3.2. Characterization of CL-AgNPs 3.2.1 FTIR analysis
FTIR spectroscopy of biomaterial CL-AgNPs was analysed in the frequency range of 400-4000 cm-1 as shown in fig S3. Spectral analysis revealed the presence of following stretching vibrations at 3425, 2923, 1740, 1632, 1383, 1103 and 619. The most prominent peak is observed at 3425 cm-1 corresponding to O―H stretching confirming the presence of phenols and alcohols. These functional groups are involved in the reduction of Ag into silver nanoparticles [47,48]. The peak at 2923 cm-1 represent C―H stretch assigned to the class of alkanes and band at 1740 cm-1 reflect C―C stretching. The band at 1632 cm-1 shows N―H (R―NH2), NH2 (R―CO―NH2) stretching, a class of amines and amides related to proteins. It has been reported that proteins can bind to silver nanoparticles and helps in reduction of silver ions [30]. 1383, 1103 and 619 band has been assigned to RCO―O bending, stretch, C―O stretch of alcoholic group, #C―H stretch [39]. FTIR analysis confirms the presence of plant metabolites such as amino acids, terpenoids and flavonoids which plays a vital role in bioreduction of silver ions [24]. 3.2.1. XPS analysis
XPS analysis was performed at Ag 3d core levels to determine the oxidation states of silver in CL-AgNPs. Fig. 1c shows wide scan survey of biomaterial CL-AgNPs which

Binding energy for silver nanoparticles corresponding to the Ag3d3/2 and Ag3d5/2 core levels appear at 373.9 eV and 367.9 eV respectively, indicating the presence of metallic silver. The crystallinity of the synthesized material was determined using powdered-XRD and the results were analyzed using PAN analytical X’ Pert high score software. The spectra of both raw CL peels and CL-AgNPs (Fig. 2) were obtained between 2θ values of 5 to 90° with a scanning rate of 1° per min for the analysis of phase and crystallinity of nanoparticles. Biological synthesis using plant extract leads to the production of crystalline silver nanoparticles which was further matched with the cubic Ag structure (JCPDS PDF file no. 04-0783) with d-spacing of 0.2368 nm [10,15]. The spectrum shows peaks at (2θ) 37.994°, 44.184°, 64.28°, and 77.233° which corresponds to (111), (200), (220) and (311) planes respectively. Sharp peak at 111 plane shows that majority of the particles are in FCC structure. Similar results were obtained in the recent work by Jacob Jo ur na l P

3.2.3. FE-SEM, EDS and HRTEM characterization of CL-AgNPs
The surface morphology, elemental distribution of the synthesized CL-AgNPs was analyzed based on imaging using FESEM. Fig. 3a and 3b shows SEM imaging and the EDS spectra (Fig. 3d) indicating elemental distribution of synthesized biomaterial CLAgNPs respectively. SEM imaging illustrates the change in morphology of washed peels and treated sample. Washed peels seemed to be smooth while the treated sample appeared to be porous due to reaction between silver ions from the solution and reducing agents present in CL peels. The porous nature infers that silver nanoparticles were entrapped into the biomass. From EDS analysis, silver content was found to be 7.25 wt%. From the surface plasmon resonance, an absorption peak is observed at 3 KeV which confirms the formation of metallic silver particles [32,51]. The shape and the size distribution of the particles were examined with HRTEM. Fig. 3c shows that the silver nanoparticles were uniformly distributed and were spherical in shape with the size distribution between 5-10 nm. A very narrow range of particle size distribution (5-14 nm) was also reported for the silver nanoparticles using citrus sinensis extract which is line with our experimental results [32].

The antibacterial activity of developed biomaterial CL-AgNPs and C. limetta peels extract was assessed against common water borne pathogens like Staphylococcus aureus ATCC 29213, Methicillin resistant S. aureus (MRSA-ST4423), laboratory strain Escherichia coli ATCC 25922, Shiga toxin-producing pathogenic Escherichia coli O157:H7, Klebsiella pneumoniae (KN233), Salmonella typhi, Pseudomonas aeruginosa (RPT-56) and Salmonella typhimurium ATCC 13311 (Table 1). As shown in Table 1, CL-AgNPs exhibit significant antibacterial activity against all tested strains with zone of inhibition ranging from 8-12 mm whereas, C. limetta peels did not show any antibacterial activity under the concentrations and conditions tested. The findings of this diffusion assay were corroborated by minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) (Table 1) estimations. As shown in Table 1, CL-AgNPs exhibit significant antibacterial activity against all tested strains with MICs ranging from 0.3-2 µg/mL. MIC was recorded as the lowest concentration at which no visible growth of the test pathogens was observed as per CLSI guidelines. Further, the bactericidal potential of both CL-AgNPs and C. limetta peels against water borne pathogens was also assessed in both batch and continuous set of experiments using sludge collected from wastewater treatment plant at Haridwar, India. The bacterial colony counts (CFU/mL) in untreated waste sludge were in the order of 2.8×106 CFU/mL. In batch experiments, about 99.5% reduction in microbial load was observed within first 5 min treatment of wastewater with CL-AgNPs. With the increase in contact time over 10-30 min, almost complete reduction in microbial load was observed in comparison to untreated control (Fig. 4a). There was no significant decrease in the microbial load in samples treated with C. limetta peels alone. The bactericidal potential of CL-AgNPs in continuous mode of experiments was also evaluated. continuous experiments also followed the similar results showing complete eradication of microbes from wastewater after treatment with CL-AgNPs within initial 10 min whereas, no significant reduction in microbial load was observed in wastewater culture after treatment with C. limetta peels. Both the batch and continuous experimental results conveyed that developed biomaterial CL-AgNPs possesses excellent antibacterial activity. Previous research works also showed antibacterial activity of AgNps against both Gram positive (Escherichia coli) and Gram negative (Staphylococcus aureus) species [52, 53]. The research works stated that AgNPs may penetrate or attach to the cell membrane altering the functions of cell leading to their death. In a similar manner, for both batch and continuous mode of operation: CL-AgNPs diffuse easily inside the bacterial cells and damage the bacterial membrane which results in the cell death.
3.4 Membrane permeabilization potential of CL-AgNPs
Silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) have been reported to adhere on bacterial cell wall and subsequently penetrate inside the bacterial cells, resulting in structural changes of the cell membrane and thus increasing its permeability [52]. AgNPs were also reported to generate hydroxyl free radicals which result in the damage of bacterial cell membrane and eventually leading to bacterial cell death [54, 55]. In order to see the effect of CLAgNPs on bacterial cell membrane, the membrane permeabilization assays were carried out. CL-AgNPs induced membrane permeabilization of both E.coli and S. aureus cells was visualized by fluorescence microscopy using fluorescent probes SYTO9 and PI which selectively stain live and dead cells, respectively. treated have been presented in Fig. 5 and Fig. 6. It can be clearly seen from Fig. 5a and Fig 6a that untreated control bacterial cells appeared predominantly green (demonstrating live cells); whereas the CL-AgNPs treated cells appeared substantially red (indicating dead cells). This finding was later corroborated with PI uptake assay. As shown in Fig. 5b and 6b, in the CL-AgNPs treated cells (both in S. aureus and E.coli), an increase in fluorescence and concomitant uptake by the bacterial cells was observed while, untreated cells of both E.coli and S. aureus carried a scant PI fluorescence signal, suggesting that they had intact and viable cell membranes. Further, the effect of synthesized CL-AgNPs and C. limetta peels on bacterial cell morphology using FE-SEM was also analyzed. As shown in Fig 7a and 7d, untreated bacterial cells (both E. coli and S. aureus) were smooth and free from any damage resulting showed their typical known shapes and size. Dramatic changes in the bacterial morphology was observed after treatment with CLAgNPs in both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacterial strains (E. coli and S. aureus cells) respectively as compared to untreated control cells. In the case of E. coli cells (Fig. 7c), complete cell burst and black spots were observed on cells after treatment with CLAgNPs as compared to untreated cells. The obtained experimental results are in agreement with the reported AgNPs action on E. coli cells [10]. Similarly, in the case of S. aureus cells (Fig. 7f), complete rupture of bacterial cells was observed as compared to untreated cells indicating strong antibacterial effect of CL-AgNPs. The combined results of both membrane permeabilization and SEM data suggested that CL-AgNPs damaged the bacterial cell membrane and might inhibit the activity of some membrane associated enzymes, which causes the bacterial cells (E. coli and S. aureus) to die eventually. The obtained antibacterial results and the mentioned mechanism concurrent with the previous Jo ur n l P re -p r of
reported research works of AgNPs on E. coli and S. aureus [10,55,56]. As shown in Fig. 7b and 7e, C. limetta peels did not show any bactericidal potential under the concentrations tested.
3.5 Haemolysis assay and cell viability
The release of haemoglobin from human RBCs exposed to different concentrations of CL-AgNPs was assessed to assess its toxicity [44]. The RBC’s were exposed to CLAgNPs and C. limetta peels extract and further, the images were captured. In addition, the absorbance at 540 nm of the supernatant was taken to account for haemoglobin release after RBC lysis. The images and absorbance data showed no interference with RBC’s when treated with different concentrations of CL-AgNPs (1× MIC, 2× MIC, 5× MIC and 10× MIC) and 100µg/mL of C. limetta peels extract. In contrast, Triton X-100 completely lysed RBCs (100% haemolysis) significantly even at a low concentration of 1% (v/v) (Fig. S5). These results infer that the developed material is likely to be non-toxic and biocompatible to mammalian system.
Amongst the various enteric pathogens, Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus are causal agents of various types of infections [1]. These pathogens along with other enteric pathogens like Salmonella and Klebsiella in the domestic sewage lead to spread of infections, especially under ineffective sewage treatments and unhygienic sanitary practices. Using biological enzymatic properties of the abundantly available C. limetta peel, it is possible to synthesize biogenic CL-AgNPs which possess impressive bacterial mitigation potential. 4. Conclusion
A new simple, eco-friendly and low-cost synthesis route was employed to synthesize silver nanoparticles using raw Citrus limetta peels. Possibly the reductase enzymes present in the peels lead to the formation of zero valent silver and hence the nano-Silver forms with a size of 5-10 nm. The CL-AgNPs were found to be non-toxic to human RBCs well beyond their MIC values. The developed material was found to be highly active exhibiting antibacterial activity against different species as compared to citrus peels. Maximum MIC of 1.2 µg/mL was observed for Pseudomonas aeruginosa (RPT-56) with zone of inhibition as 7 mm. MIC of 0.3 µg/mL has been found to be lowest for the species Staphylococcus aureus 29213 and Escherichia Coli 25922 with zone of inhibition as 8 and 9 mm respectively. In addition, CL-AgNPs were also tested against the sludge of WWTP both in batch and continuous operations. The biomaterial was found to mitigate the bacterial species within short span of contact (≤ 5 min). Further detailed studies are required for in-depth understanding of bacterial mitigation potential of biosynthesized CL-AgNPs on aerobic and anaerobic treatment in wastewater systems. metadata.abstractText: Water borne pathogens pose a great threat to the health-care system and their mitigation poses a formidable challenge prompting researchers to find innovative and effective methods for pathogen control. Large scale implementation technologies for wastewater treatment need to be economical and facile. We have utilized industrial waste from citrus fruits to develop green nano-biocomposite materials. Green nano-biosynthesis methods are known to be cost effective, non-toxic and environment friendly that have attracted attention recently. The present study utilized citrus industry waste raw Citrus limetta peels as bio-reducing and stabilizing agents directly, instead of extract for the synthesis of silver nanoparticles. Characterization of the synthesized silver nanoparticles by X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) confirmed the impregnation of nano-silver with size range of 5-10 nm inside Citrus limetta peels that has been designated as CL-AgNPs. Antibacterial activity of CL-AgNPs was evaluated against the most prevalent waterborne pathogens for treating waste water from domestic and municipalities. The antibacterial activity was linked to nano-silver’s membrane permeabilization mode using LIVE/DEAD staining technique. The antibacterial potential of CL-AgNPs was also tested in batch and continuous experiments separately, which showed attenuation in bacterial load within 5 min exposure of CL-AgNPs as demonstrated by growth kinetics study. Furthermore, CL-AgNPs was found to be safe and did not exhibit cytotoxiceffects on human red blood cells (RBCs) up to 10X MIC. These findings infer that CL-AgNPs could be employed for cost-effective treatment of contaminated waste water after process optimization. Jo ur n l P re -p r of
